ygData.subject: Letting NEAT Decide Which Inputs to Use
ygData.msgSnippet: A number of people like John have recently brought up letting NEAT decide for itself which inputs it should use.  (As an example the below quote is from John)

Subject: Letting NEAT Decide Which Inputs to Use
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

A number of people like John have recently brought up letting NEAT
decide for itself which inputs it should use.  (As an example the
below quote is from John)

If you intend to let NEAT do this, please read this complete message,
which contains important information on starting NEAT with some inputs
disconnected.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:

> 
> Input node 'a' is connected with weight 1 to all output nodes 'a'. 
Same for 
> b, c, and d.  This corresponds exactly to a 'nearest neighbor' or
'pixel 
> enlargement' algorithm.  The remaining input nodes are unconnected
in the 
> hopes that NEAT will decide for itself which nodes it needs and
which it 
> does not.  I expect it to ultimately connect to all of them, but
with how 
> many hidden nodes? 

I want to let people on this group know that this is a good idea but
you should be aware that some versions of NEAT (including my own and
Ugo's JNEAT) require some slight modification to make this possible. 
The reason for this is that NEAT was originally programmed to drop
nodes during crossover that were not connected to anything.  Thus, if
you start NEAT with some inputs disconnected, they will end up getting
dropped and lost!

The solution is simply to tell NEAT not to do this.  I have provided a
detailed explanation of how to get this working at:

http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html#disconnected

which is now a newly added question in the NEAT FAQ on the Users page.

Anyone who does try this and still  finds problems (such as nodes
being lost over generations) please let me know.  I have personally
implemented genomes in this way (with some inputs disconnected) and
found NEAT successful at adding them as needed through new
connections, so I know it is possible.  In addition, Shimon Whiteson
(who is my officemate here at UT) has implemented a sophisticated
version of this process in JNEAT, which Shimon called FS-NEAT or
"Feature Selective NEAT."

ken
